title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: What did itmatter if it abruptly summoned Miss Tabitha Shankspindle,a spinster of uncertain summers, to say nothing of temper,from her virtuous couch in the adjoining house, under theimpression that her everlasting apprehension—the igniting ofher kitchen chimney—had overtaken her at last? Whatsignified it, also, if Major Macrackitpate, late of the BengalFirst Jungle Fencibles—a planter by calling, a soldier bycourtesy—who slept in the flat below, and who likewise hadbeen aroused by the chorus, conceiving that the savageRanipuris of the hids had come down in force to sack hisstation, at once barricaded his bedroom door, and retired belowthe bed to await developments ? Such little surface ripples onthe stagnant pool of Alva Street society soon subsided, uponthe consideration of the fact that " it was juist thae studentlads amusin' themselves, puh callants ! "

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: What did it matter if the strains poured forth from a trioof young and lusty throats diffused widespread consternationamong the decorous denizens of Alva Street? What did itmatter if it abruptly summoned Miss Tabitha Shankspindle,a spinster of uncertain summers, to say nothing of temper,from her virtuous couch in the adjoining house, under theimpression that her everlasting apprehension—the igniting ofher kitchen chimney—had overtaken her at last?

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: In the comfortably furnished sitting-room of a well-knownboarding-house in Alva Street sat three young men, discussingover a glass of " Glenlivet" and innumerable pipes of " bird'seye " and Latakia, the events of the College session just closed. They were all about the same age—namely, twenty-two—wereall classmates, and finally were all contemplating the pursuit ofthe same profession—the law.
